entry.title: Measuring education: What data is available?
entry.summary: The idea for this document is to give an overview of the metrics that are used to monitor the educational structure of populations especially in international comparisons. As the focus is on international comparisons I have made sure to list all the metrics and datasets that are included in the World Bank's extensive EdStats data catalogue. With all the many measures on attainment and enrollment, in gross and net rates, ISCED levels, etc. etc. it can be difficult to understand what education data actually refers to. I hope this document is useful as a reference for some.

entry.title: How many people in the world die from cancer?
entry.summary: Every sixth death in the world is due to cancer, making it the second leading cause of death (second only to cardiovascular diseases).1 In 2016, 8.9 million people are estimated to have died from the various forms of cancer. The Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME) put relatively small error margins around this global figure: the lower and upper estimates extend from 8.75 to 9.1 million.2 Progress against many other causes of deaths and demographic drivers of increasing population size, life expectancy and — particularly in higher-income countries — aging populations mean that the total number of cancer deaths continues to increase. This is a very personal topic to many: nearly everyone knows or has lost someone dear to them from this collection of diseases.
